Headline.Para: 2018 Nissan Leaf: A Worthy Electric Rival for the Chevy Bolt? Starting seven grand cheaper than the Bolt, the redesigned Nissan Leaf EV got an upgrade in range to 151 miles on a full charge. Dan Neil ponders its relative virtue

LeadPara.Para: ONE OF THE OLDEST and lamest arguments against electric vehicles is called the "long tailpipe." EVs aren't any cleaner than gasoline-powered cars, this song goes; they just move their greenhouse-gas emissions to the power plants charging the grid.

It is certainly true that EVs are only as clean as the grid that charges them. But the United States power grid is getting cleaner all the time, due mostly to the decline in the use of coal, down about 20% in a decade. In February the Environmental Protection Agency released its annual report on power plant greenhouse-gas emissions (data from 2016). A well-to-wheel analysis by the Union of Concerned Scientists found that the average carbon emissions of a grid-charged EV was equivalent to a gas-powered car getting 80 mpg.

TailParas.Para: Because regional grids have different mixes of power generation, the carbon impact varies depending on where the car is charged: In most of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, it's a mere 38 mpg. In California, the largest car market, the figure is 109 mpg.
In any event, EVs are cleaner than gas-powered vehicles, full stop.

I bring this up because of Aristotle, who observed that there were two kinds of happiness: one based on pleasure (hedonia); the other on virtue and clean living (eudaimonia). Aristotle was cribbing a bit from Democritus, actually, but in those days footnotes were heavy and hard to carve.

Likewise, there are two kinds of car happiness. In the hedonic category you might find the Chevrolet Camaro LS1: rumbling, raging, mad with power, subtle as a mink-lined jockstrap. In a Camaro carbon emissions are kind of the point.

The Nissan Leaf, on the other hand, wears its eudaimonia like a frumpy toga. Thrifty, modest, resolutely appliance-like, this family hatchback was the world's first mass-market EV (2010) and still holds the title as the best-selling EV in history.

It didn't get there on its looks, obviously. The first-gen Leaf's styling weirdness—especially the headlamps, like giant glass leeches—almost seemed purposeful, as if to suggest Leaf buyers had pierced the illusions of car ownership and were above the vanity and status-seeking of a quote-unquote pretty car.

New for 2018, the second-gen Leaf turns down the virtue signaling a bit. The baby sandshark nose has been replaced with Nissan's V-shaped grille design, with a jazzy inset of clear blue plastic. The swelling around the headlamps has gone down.

Early and late, the Leaf's biggest deficit has been its lack of range. The original design was built around a 24-kWh air-cooled battery pack, providing an EPA-rated range of just 73 miles. This was as much battery as Nissan could afford and it still drove the price to $33,600. Nissan had plausible reasons to hedge small. In 2009, the U.S. Department of Transportation found the average daily driving distance of urban-based cars was just 36.5 miles; for rural-based cars, the figure was 48.6 miles.
But it wasn't enough, not really. The best the first-gen Leaf could do was 107 miles with the optional 30 kWh battery (2016). These cars practically invented range anxiety.

In 2017 GM delivered the Chevrolet Bolt, similar in size and function to the Leaf, powered by a 60-kWh battery pack providing 238 miles of range. The Bolt promptly began outselling the Leaf by more than two-to-one.

The new Leaf steps up to a more energy-dense battery (40 kWh) providing 151 miles of range, but that's still 87 miles short of the Bolt. To compete, the Leaf has been obliged to play the value entry. With a base price of $29,990, the Leaf starts a cool seven grand cheaper than the Bolt.

Our test car, an SL, carried an MSRP of $36,200, including navigation, leather seats, Bose audio system, heated front seats and steering wheel, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. It was also equipped with the tech package ($650), bundling Nissan's suite of driver's assistance functions called ProPilot Assist. With the available federal plug-in vehicle tax credit of $7,500, our test car would have penciled out to $30,630. It may not go as far as the Bolt, but the Leaf's generosity of equipment is pretty persuasive.

Let's start with the box: The Leaf is majority-steel unit-body construction, enclosing 92.4 cubic feet of passenger space (a bit less than the Bolt) and 23.6 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seatback (a bit more). It's a five-passenger vehicle, officially, but the hump in the floor makes the middle-seat almost unusable for bipeds. The front-mounted electric motor generates 147 hp (up 37%) and 236 pound-feet of torque, sufficient to propel the Leaf to 60 mph in about 7.5 seconds, front tires chirping merrily.

The Leaf has a built-in 6.6 kWh charger. A full charge from 0 takes 7.5 hours at a Level 2 charger. Under the nose hatch is a J1772 socket; the SV and SL trim levels also get CHAdeMO socket. The Leaf comes with two years free charging (DC fast and Level 2) from participating No Charge to Charge stations. The locator map says there are 67 in the Raleigh, N.C. area.

The drive experience is friendly, dutiful, unremarkable. The Leaf is quick off the line, stable in corners (the low-slung batteries) and quiet, humming like the proverbial bee-loud glade. The front bucket seats are plush and comfortable. You can get four sets of golf clubs in the Leaf, if any owner ever takes up the game.

To extract the maximum miles from the Leaf it helps to engage e-Pedal mode, using the pull switch on the center console. The e-Pedal increases the regenerative braking effect and gives the Leaf essentially one-pedal operation. Lighten pressure on the accelerator and the Leaf slows down; remove your foot altogether and the car comes to a stop, pretty vigorously too, while charging the battery.
Waste nothing, says Aristotle.
